awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Collaborative Research: Supermassive Binary Black Hole Mergers: Accretion Dynamics and Electromagnetic Output
awd_abstract_narration:
Supermassive black hole (SMBH) mergers are one of the most dramatic phenomena in the Universe.  For a few hours, they can emit as much power in gravitational waves as all the stars in the Universe produce in light.  However, none has yet been caught in the act, partly because no one knows what sort of light they should emit along with the gravitational waves.   This project combines astrophysical knowledge of SMBH binaries with detailed physical simulation of gas flows and explicit computation of time-dependent spacetimes, to predict the light observers should search for.  Junior researchers will learn about this new field and about very large-scale computation, strengthening the technical workforce. Ancillary efforts by the PIs enhance the teaching program at each of their universities and contribute to public outreach.

This group has built the knowledge base and computational methods needed to make these predictions, including building a multi-patch simulation infrastructure to compute the changing spacetime and permit separate treatment of subregions.  The code base includes post-processing tools that transform fluid simulation data into predictions of photon radiation, accounting for the principal radiation mechanisms, opacities, and photon propagation through dynamical spacetimes.  This study starts at the immediate pre-merger state, to understand its physical mechanisms and to prepare realistic initial data.  The second step will compute how matter behaves during the merger proper and the subsequent relaxation phase.  The post-processing machinery then predicts EM spectra and light curves.  This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supermassive binary black holes represent some of the universe's most intriguing and powerful phenomena. As two massive black holes gradually spiral together, they consume everything around them, eventually merging in a spectacular event. These cosmic occurrences not only captivate scientists due to their massive scale but also because they are anticipated to emit two crucial types of signals: gravitational waves and electromagnetic radiation. This makes them prime candidates for study in multimessenger astronomy—a field that integrates diverse signals to deepen our understanding of cosmic events.
A team from the Rochester Institute of Technology, in collaboration with Johns Hopkins University, has launched a research initiative to predict the unique electromagnetic signatures associated with supermassive binary black holes. Their goal is to enhance the capability of telescopes and other observational tools to detect these extraordinary phenomena, thereby advancing our understanding of the dynamic processes shaping the universe. This research aims to unlock new insights into these cosmic mergers and advance astronomy by combining gravitational and electromagnetic observations.
To achieve this, the team developed advanced simulations to model gas dynamics around colliding supermassive black holes. Using novel computational tools, they simulated the entire sequence of events—from the initial approach of these massive bodies to their eventual merger and subsequent formation of a single supermassive black hole. The project integrates principles of general relativity and magnetohydrodynamics, employing realistic approximations to account for radiation and emissions from accreting gas. These simulations offer critical insights into gas flows around such systems, examining how variables such as mass ratios, spins, and eccentricities influence observable signals. The results accurately depict the trajectory of these binaries from distant approach to post-merger, providing valuable predictions for future observation missions.
This research has significant implications both for the scientific community and society at large. With upcoming missions like the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna and Pulsar Timing Arrays on the horizon, the simulation data will be vital for detecting and analyzing gravitational wave emissions from supermassive black holes. Additionally, the research contributes to refining the techniques employed by current and future National Science Foundation observatories, such as the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, enhancing their ability to monitor and study these cosmic events.
Moreover, this project advances the field of multimessenger astrophysics by supporting the integration of observational data, including gravitational waves and electromagnetic signals, providing a comprehensive understanding of cosmic events. Insights from this research are paramount in identifying supermassive black hole mergers and enhancing our understanding of the universe’s structure and evolution.
Through this initiative, a new generation of scientists is being trained, equipping them with essential skills to explore these complex astrophysical phenomena, thereby ensuring ongoing exploration and discovery in this exciting field and fostering advancements in our comprehension of the cosmos.
